ok so no one is responding on #svn
What are you having trouble with?
i followed tutorials
Are you following a guide?
Are you trying to set up a server?
just to use it as a client?
Alright, which tutorial?
just so I know what steps they're having you go through
http://www.howtogeek.com/howto/ubuntu/install-subversion-with-web-access-on-ubuntu/
Alright.

In general howtogeek is a horrible place for accurate tutorials (for Debian based systems, they tend to do things the RPM based way), but this one looks pretty accurate (mostly because its straightforward).
What steps are you having trouble with?
or just 'get to end, stuff don't work'?
Alright.
That makes sense, now that I take a second look at that tutorial.
Let me ask, is your intent to do this via apache?
(http(s):// links) or do you not care what protocol?
Do you want/need the apache browsing ability?
Right.
So, you're already running apache on this machine (or don't mind running it if you're not already)?
Alright, just a couple more questions.
Do you intend for this to be local-LAN only?
or visible from the outside world?
over http or https or both?
Well, currently you're serving stuff over http but not https.
The only thing about this with regard to your svn is it means your passwords would be transmitted in plaintext.
I suggest you make sure to use a different svn password than your regular user account password.
Just be congizant of it :)
So, lets make this work.
From that tutorial, I think you have a /svn directory, is this true?
Alright, lets go ahead and delete that.
We have to re-create the repository anyway, so the least we can do is do it in a non-obnoxious location.
I'll come back to that, give me a sec.
Do you have /var on a separate (large) partition, because you're expecting to put a lot of stuff in /var/www?
or do we just have one partition with everything on it?
... why did you do that?
No worries, everyone is new at some point :)
Alright.

I'm not going to deal with that at the moment, but go ahead and pastebin the output of `df -h` (pastebin is http://planet.ubuntu.com/, you paste output, hit 'submit' then give the url here for us to look at)
Er, sorry.
paste.ubuntu.com
any directory?
just `df -h`
Alright, so we've just got everything in /, which is fine.
We're still going to put /svn in /var though, because that's where it belongs.
(There is no standard here, other than /var for variable sized data)
Personally, I made a /var/devel/ which I then put /svn/ and other things in, but you're free to just create it in /var/svn/
No, we're not moving, we're going to delete the old one: `sudo rm -r /svn` (Be very careful with that, you don't want a space in between '/' and 'svn')
No
Alright, now go ahead and make a svn folder, sudo mkdir /var/svn/ if you want it in /var/svn/ (for example, mine is /var/devel/svn/)
That's fine.
Ok.
So, in our head we realize we have to update the apache config to point there, which we'll do in a minute.
Right now, I need to ask: Is this going to be your only svn repository?
or do you think you'll have an immediate need for more than one?
We can add more later, of course, so you're not really locked in, but we can do it for '1' now or for 'many' now (with a little bit more work)
Alright, good.
Alright, I'd normally say we're ready to create it, but before, I feel compelled to ask: did you change the default user/group that apache runs as?
this would consist of replacing `www-data` with $something-else in your apache config.
This is why I asked :)  Also, did I mention howtogeek is a rotten place for tutorials yet?
If you didn't change anything, /etc/apache2/envvars would list it, BUT since you may have hardcoded it, we'll need to probably check /etc/apache2/apache2.conf.
So, the command to do that:
Nah, we'll use grep, it's easier!
Let me pause this, because this is a teaching moment.
So, `sudo` is only used when you need elevated permissions.
MOST (not all, but probably 99%) config files are world readable, so there's no reason to sudo nano /etc/apache2/apache2.conf (unless you intend to change something) or sudo grep /etc/whatever
Its not the end of the world, most of the time sudo X will work just fine, but it can cause problems, and certainly can lead to accidental changes :)
anyway, the command you can pastebin the output to is: grep User /etc/apache2/apache2.conf && grep Group /etc/apache2/apache2.conf && grep www-data /etc/apache2/envvars
All on one line (command1 && command2 && command3 means 'do command1, then if it has no errors, do command2, and the same with command3)
So that command looked first for the string 'User' in /etc/apache2/apache2.conf, then it looked for 'Group' in the same file, and then the last command looked for 'www-data' in /etc/apache2/envvars

The first two told me you haven't hard coded the values (theyre still ${APACHE_RUN_USER} and ${APACHE_RUN_GROUP}, respectively) and the last one told me you haven't changed the defaults for those settings either.
Still with me?
Or confused as heck?
(Take your time, just want to make sure you're not looking at the screen dumbfounded)
sorry had to get up for a second
No worries.
Alright.
So, the point of that was to figure out what user and group apache runs as.
You're still default, which means it runs as www-data:www-data.
right
Now that we know that, we want to make /var/svn/ owned by www-data:www-data (because the apache user is going to be how we interact with it): sudo chown www-data:www-data /var/svn/
Now, we're ready to create our svn repository.
Again, we want to do this as our apache user.
So we'll use sudo to open a shell as our apache user, then move to our subversion directory, then make a repository.
What name do you want to give this repository?
triumph
Alright.
So, `sudo -u www-data -i` (it likely won't ask for your password, but if it does, remember, it's YOUR password)
then you'll see probably nothing but a `$` prompt.
You're essentially logged in as apache right now, you can probably `ls` and see your site's files.
So we want to change to our subversion directory, `cd /var/svn/`
and then create our repository: `svnadmin create triumph`
sure
Oh, this could be due to the fact that you moved it to your homedir.
You can cd /var/svn/ and `ls` successfully though, right?
(it'll be empty, but it wont error)
No, don't do that.
That's alright.
It gave you a 'you're not allowed' message anyway, because you're www-data, right?
(even if you did it as your user, we can fix it later)
right.
So, `svnadmin create triumph`  (we could have just did `svnadmin create /var/svn/triumph` instead of cd etc too, but this is obviously more educational :)
Just in the terminal, where you're currently in /var/svn/ as www-data
Same terminal
'triumph' in that case is a relative path, 'whereever I am' being the default working directory
Alright, now we want to get out of our www-data terminal, and go back to your normal user, so we use `exit` (which is similar but different than logout)
After that, we need to go into apache and point it at our new repository location.
So... lets see, this would be in /etc/apache2/sites-available/default
At least, that's probably where it is.
You may have done it differently if you were using a different tutorial.
We want to edit that file, so `sudo nano /etc/apache2/sites-available/default` in that file you should see a <Location /svn> directive, with SVNPath /svn in it, etc.
If you don't, let me know, we'll need to find it.
No, we want the enabled one.
Alright.
Go ahead and open that, and pastebin its contents please (there shouldn't be anything sensitive in it)
That doesn't look like a complete file, but just a section of the middle of one.
(actually it looks like the end of it)
Oh, right.
Sorry, you're right!
there isn't a <Location /svn> in that file!
Because as of ... 10.04 or 8.04 or something, it's actually in /etc/apache2/mods-available/dav_svn.conf
so, go ahead and close this file, then open that (with sudo) in nano.
(and pastebin if you don't mind!)
Alright.
Now we need to change line 11, where it says SVNPath /svn, we need to move that to point to our new path, SVNPath /var/svn/triumph
Save it, restart apache, and it should be.
You should see 'Revision: 0' at http://playtriumph.tk/svn once you log in.
Which one?
Did you view http://playtriumph.tk/svn/ or  http://playtriumph.tk/svn ?
(trailing slash)
Alright.
Lets look at our apache error log, that'll tell us what it's not able to do.
pastebin `tail -n 25 /var/log/apache2/error.log` (that just displays the last (up to) 25 lines of that file)
Alright, if I had to guess, I'd say we didn't successfully update /etc/apache2/mods-available/dav_svn.conf
Actually, let me ask this instead.
Can you please pastebin the contents of /etc/apache2/mods-enabled/dav_svn.conf?
Alright, so you have (line 19): SVNPath /svn/triumph, this needs to be /var/svn/triumph

If you look at your error log, it was looking for /svn/triumph/format (format is a file in the repository that apache was looking for), which is how I knew this wasn't configured correctly (should be looking for /var/svn/triumph/format)
So, now go back to your homedir, make a scratch folder, go into it.
`svn checkout https://playtriumph.tk/svn/ .`
That'll checkout the repository (its empty) to your current working directory (which, you've made a new folder for)
Er sorry, http not https.
you can do this on your macbook pro, if you have svn installed.
At this point, your server is set up, and we're off to svn-land.
Install svn on your macbook....
I don't really know how to do that :)  We CAN do it on your server too if that's easier
http://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.7/svn.intro.quickstart.html  That book is a good book.
You oviously don't need to set up a repository, just use it, so you can skip the first svnadmin bit.
`svn` is the command
If you've got stuff you want to import, then svn import will work.
I prefer an initial structure commit first, but that's just personal preference.
svn commit -m 'message', I encourage you to peruse that page/its links (and the rest of it).
It's actually a pretty quick read for the basics (skip the reference and advanced stuff, etc)
especially if you're already familiar with git
http://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.7/svn.tour.importing.html for instance.
You need to svn add first.
You've checked out, then you copy (filesystem) then add (files from filesystem into svn), then commit.
`svn status` will tell you what has been added (not yet committed), or question marks mean 'not under version control'
`svn add file`
where file is a particular file, or a glob of files
to add your current directory?
